--- title: "5.5 — Reforming Online Data — Class Content" execute: freeze: auto --- ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.callout-note appearance=minimal} # Meeting Date *Tuesday, May 2, 2023* ::: ## Overview For this final topic, I want to discuss something I have been mulling over for a long time, but never have really explored sufficiently: how we might reform data management on the internet. This is in part a response to the rise of dominant platforms, privacy concerns, antitrust concerns, and the rise of blockchain/Web3 technology. There's a lot worth exploring here, so I recommend you look at both the Weyl and the Munger readings - each comes both as a reading and a podcast option which covers relevant ideas contained in each reading. ## Readings ### Required Readings: - [ Posner & Weyl, 2016, "Data as Labor", Chapter 5 in *Radical Markets*](/files/readings/Posner-Weyl-Ch5.pdf) - [ *Mercatus Center Hayek Program Podcast*: " Glen Weyl on the Myths and Benefits of Automation"](https://podcasts.apple.com/ca/podcast/hayek-program-podcast/id1069881407?i=1000456022970) - [ *EconTalk*: "Michael Munger on Antitrust"](https://www.econtalk.org/michael-munger-on-antitrust/) (ending starting around 1 hr 6 min mark) - [ Munger, 2022, “Three Topics for Young Political Economists”](https://www.aier.org/article/three-topics-for-young-political-economists/) ## Slides Below, you can find the slides in two formats. Clicking the image will bring you to the html version of the slides in a new tab. The lower button will allow you to download a PDF version of the slides. ::: callout-tip You can type h to see a special list of viewing options, and type o for an outline view of all the slides. ::: I suggest printing the slides beforehand and using them to take additional notes in class (*not everything* is in the slides)!

Download as PDF
